item.title: Trump Defends Bolsonaro as Trial on Coup Charges Looms
item.description: Donald Trump accused Brazil of politically persecuting Jair Bolsonaro, launching a strident defense of the right-wing former president who is set to face trial on charges that he attempted a coup.
item.dc:creator: Travis Waldron, Leda Alvim

media:content.media:description: Brazil's former president Jair Bolsonaro

item.title: Trump to Levy 25% Tariffs on Japan, South Korea in August
item.description: President Donald Trump announced tariffs of 25% on goods from Japan and South Korea beginning on Aug. 1, as he moved to impose unilateral rates on countries that have not yet secured trade deals with his administration.
item.dc:creator: Brendan Murray, Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: A transfer crane unloads a container onto a truck in a shipping terminal at the Honmoku pier in Yokohama, Japan.

item.title: KLM to Lend Pilots to Dutch Air Force for Fighter Jet Duties
item.description: Dutch flag carrier KLM agreed to lend pilots to the country’s air force, increasing the airline’s cooperation with the defense ministry after criticism it was poaching military aviators.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Van Oosterom

media:content.media:description: A Dutch Lockheed Martin F-35 Lightning II fighter jet.

item.title: Trump Immigration Enforcer Says ICE Will Boost Raids in New York
item.description: Tom Homan, the border czar for President Donald Trump, said that immigration agents will ramp up arrests in New York City as part of a broader crackdown on sanctuary jurisdictions that limit cooperation with federal authorities.
item.dc:creator: Myles Miller

media:content.media:description: Tom Homan, White House border czar, speaks to members of the media outside the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, June 19, 2025. Homan, asked about concerns from farmers that immigration enforcement is harming them, says there is a right and wrong way to hire.

item.title: Guyana Opposition Taps Aubrey Norton as Its Presidential Candidate
item.description: Guyana’s main opposition group announced veteran politician Aubrey Norton as its presidential candidate, promising to use growing oil production to deliver higher wages and other social programs.

item.title: Donohoe Retains Eurogroup Role to Push Currency’s Ascendancy
item.description: Paschal Donohoe won reelection as president of the euro area’s group of finance ministers, retaining a leading role in the region’s efforts to enhance the profile of its common currency.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Valero, Michal Kubala, Daniel Basteiro, Milda Seputyte

As Donald Trump prepares to be sworn in as president today, Europe's leaders are bracing for the first batch of executive orders and their potential impact on the region. Photographer: Simon Wohlfahrt/Bloomberg

item.title: Ramaphosa Blasts Back at Trump Over Threatened Tariffs on BRICS
item.description: South African President Cyril Ramaphosa stepped in to an escalating spat with Donald Trump over the US president’s threats targeting the BRICS group, saying that “it cannot be that might should now be right.”
item.dc:creator: S'thembile Cele, Simone Iglesias, Mirette Magdy

media:content.media:description: South Africa's President Cyril Ramaphosa attends a BRICS summit session in Rio de Janeiro, on July 6.

item.title: EU Says It’s Making Progress on Framework Trade Deal With US
item.description: The European Union said it’s closing in on a framework trade agreement with the US after the head of the bloc’s executive arm, Ursula von der Leyen, held a call with President Donald Trump on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Valero, Michael Nienaber, Alberto Nardelli

media:content.media:description: Harbor ferry boats pass the Port of Hamburg in Hamburg, Germany, on Monday, Feb. 3, 2025. A global trade war is heating up and Germany’s biggest seaport, like the country at large, is steeling itself for what may be to come.

item.title: Russia Probes Suicide After Ex-Transport Minister Found Dead
item.description: Former Russian Transportation Minister Roman Starovoit died in an apparent suicide, the country’s investigative committee said in a statement on Monday, hours after he was dismissed from his post.
item.dc:creator: Greg Sullivan

media:content.media:description: Roman Starovoyt in May.

item.title: Iran President Tells Tucker Carlson He’s Open to Talks With US
item.description: Iranian President Masoud Pezeshkian told Tucker Carlson his country remains open to talks with the US, but that it was difficult to trust Washington after its strikes last month.

item.title: ICE Raids Derail Los Angeles Economy as Workers Go Missing
item.description: Los Angeles was already struggling to revive its fragile economy after the most destructive wildfires in its history erupted six months ago. Now, immigration raids are driving workers crucial to the rebuilding into the shadows.
item.dc:creator: John Gittelsohn

media:content.media:description: A closed car wash after a federal immigration raid took place there in Culver City, California, on June 11.

item.title: Rubio to Make First Trip to Asia as Tariffs Deadline Looms
item.description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio is set to make his first trip to Asia as top US diplomat this week to discuss trade and security with regional counterparts who are looking to avoid President Donald Trump’s looming tariff increases.
item.dc:creator: Eric Martin

media:content.media:description: Signage for the 46th Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) Summit in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. Photographer: He Guowei/VCG/Getty Images

item.title: Turkey Ramps Up Opposition Probes, Keeping Markets on Edge
item.description: Turkey launched an investigation into the main opposition party’s leader and arrested more of its mayors, in a widening crackdown that’s likely to stoke investor anxiety over risks to the rule of law and political stability.
item.dc:creator: Ugur Yilmaz, Tugce Ozsoy

media:content.media:description: Ozgur Ozel, leader of Turkey's main opposition Republican People's Party (CHP), gives a speech during an extraordinary congress of the party in Ankara on April 6, 2025. Until now the relatively low-profile head of the CHP, Ozel is expected to be re-elected after ten days of protests sparked by the arrest of its kingpin, the mayor of Istanbul. (Photo by Adem ALTAN / AFP) (Photo by ADEM ALTAN/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Four Dead in Kenya Protests as Police Shut Capital City Down
item.description: The streets of downtown Nairobi were deserted and many store fronts were soldered shut as workers and traders stayed away on fears that protests demanding the removal of President William Ruto may turn violent.
item.dc:creator: Simon Marks, David Herbling

media:content.media:description: A man walks past a barbed wire barricade set up by police outside parliament ahead of possible Saba Saba Day demonstrations in Nairobi on July 7, 2025. Kenya marked its fight for democracy on July 7, 2025 with police blocking main roads in Nairobi ahead of potential protests, after last month's demonstrations descended into violent clashes. Saba Saba Day marks the uprising on July 7, 1990 when Kenyans demanded a return to multi-party democracy after years of autocratic rule by then-president Daniel arap Moi. (Photo by Tony KARUMBA / AFP) (Photo by TONY KARUMBA/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: BRICS Tread With Caution After Trump Threatens New Tariffs
item.description: BRICS officials kept their collective heads down on Monday morning as they awoke to an overnight threat by US President Donald Trump to penalize them for adopting policies he said were “anti-American.”
item.dc:creator: Simone Iglesias, Mirette Magdy

media:content.media:description: Brazil's President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva during a BRICS summit plenary session on July 6.

item.title: Bessent Aims to Meet With Chinese Counterpart in Next Few Weeks
item.description: US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said that he expected to meet with his Chinese counterpart in the coming weeks to advance discussions on trade and other issues between the world’s two largest economies.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent, US secretary of the treasury, speaks to members of the media after a Senate Republican policy luncheon at the US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, June 27, 2025. President Donald Trump amped up pressure on Congress to speed the passage of his tax-cut bill as Republicans reached a tentative deal on the state and local tax deduction, one of the key sticking points in the negotiations.

item.title: UK Declines to Rule Out Wealth Tax as Pressure Mounts on Reeves
item.description: The UK government declined to rule out imposing a new tax on Britain’s wealthiest people, as Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves faces growing calls from prominent left-wing figures to introduce such a levy.

item.title: Deadly Floods Reinforce Texas’ Challenge as Crisis Epicenter
item.description: Before dawn Friday morning, city manager Dalton Rice went for a jog along the Guadalupe River in Kerrville, Texas. He finished his run around 4 a.m. as a light rain set in. An hour later, he began receiving emergency calls: The river had flooded out of control.
item.dc:creator: Brian K Sullivan, Maria Paula Mijares Torres, Joe Lovinger, Mary Hui

item.title: Zelenskiy Spoke With Trump on Replacing Kyiv’s Envoy to US
item.description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy discussed replacing the current ambassador to the US during his phone call with President Donald Trump on Friday, according to a person familiar with the matter.

item.title: Ramaphosa Ally Tied to Stalling South Africa Assassination Probe
item.description: South African President Cyril Ramaphosa faces a fresh crisis within his government after a senior police official accused one of his ministers of interference in an investigation into political assassinations.
item.dc:creator: Antony Sguazzin

media:content.media:description: Cyril Ramaphosa, South Africa's president, during a news conference following a meeting with Volodymyr Zelenskiy, Ukraine's president, at the Union Buildings in Pretoria, South Africa, on Thursday, April 24, 2025. President Volodymyr Zelenskiy became the fist leader of Ukraine to visit South Africa in a bid to expand diplomatic outreach while he can no longer fully rely on US as his nation’s key ally and the peace deal with Russia remains elusive.

item.title: Bangladesh Expects ‘Positive Outcome’ With US on Trade Deal
item.description: Bangladesh’s interim government is anticipating a favorable resolution in trade negotiations with the US, after being among the hardest hit by President Donald Trump’s sweeping tariffs in April.

media:content.media:description: Container cranes lie non-operational at the Chittagong Port in Chittagong on June 29, 2025, as export and import activities remained suspended due to an ongoing protest by employees of the National Board of Revenue (NBR) over reform issues by Bangladesh's interim government. (Photo by AFP) (Photo by -/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Trump Administration Adds 60 Facilities for Detained Migrants
item.description: The expansion has added thousands of beds to ICE capacity, as the department prepares for an influx of cash from Congress
item.dc:creator: Alicia A. Caldwell, Elena Mejia

media:content.media:description: Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents stand near a gate as they watch protestors at a demonstration in Elizabeth, New Jersey May 7, 2025, outside Delaney Hall, a newly converted immigrant detention centre. Delaney Hall has the ability to hold over a 1000 people, and the detention facility, privately owned by The GEO Group, holds a contract with the federal government to house people arrested by ICE.

item.title: Trump Warns of 10% Tariff for ‘Anti-American’ BRICS Policies
item.description: President Donald Trump said he would put an additional 10% tariff on any country aligning themselves with “the Anti-American policies of BRICS,” injecting further uncertainty into global trade as the US continues to negotiate levies with many trading partners.

item.title: Portugal Sees EU, US Reaching Deal With ‘Very Low’ Tariffs
item.description: Portuguese Finance Minister Joaquim Miranda Sarmento said he sees the European Union and the US reaching an agreement with tariffs potentially below 10% that would help keep trade flowing.

item.title: China’s Retaliation to EU Curbs Blurs Ties Before Summit
item.description: China hit back at the European Union’s restrictions on its medical device makers while maintaining key exceptions, adding uncertainty to ties ahead of a high-stakes summit later this month.
item.dc:creator: Colum Murphy, Amber Tong
